title: Visual Criminology: Crime, Criminal Justice, and the Image
abstractText:
Recent years have seen a resurgence of interest in the visual dimensions of crime and justice. As images of crime, harm and punishment proliferate across new and old media there is a growing recognition that criminology needs to rethink its relations with the power of spectacle. In this seminar series we propose a focussed exploration of the role played by these images in reframing criminological inquiry, which will significantly advance thinking on the topic in and beyond the discipline.

The seminars aim to consolidate, systematise and further explore an emerging field of inquiry, ie 'visual criminology' by focussing on a number of interconnected themes:

  • ‘The Image, Accused' and ‘The Image, Accusing'
  • 'Images of Criminal Space' and 'The Movement of Deviant Images'
  • 'Images Explaining Crime' and 'The Criminal Image Explained'
  • ‘The Uses of the Image in Crime Control and Criminal Justice’
  • ‘Images of Crime Control and Criminal Justice’.
